transcripts.text: Let's get to International Men's Day.  Bettina Arndt, there's not much hoopla about it.

No.  Why not?  I'm hearing from men all over the country who say, oh, my organisation, my company, whatever I work for, constantly promotes International Women's Day.  In fact, even one of the firefighters said to me that they had this big thing for International Women's Day.  And why does it try to get the companies to do something for men?  Nothing.

But I suppose the whole point is that men have been dominant historically, had unfair preference historically, and the whole idea of International Women's Day is to try and redress the balance and and encourage women to get more...
Don't you think the balance has been redressed?
I'm talking about when it was started up.
Decades ago.

And you would argue, and others, that there are very serious issues confronting men that need to be looked at.  Men are by far the majority of suicides, for instance, even victims of domestic violence.
And we have a gender-neutral suicide policy.  We won't address any real issue that affects men.  because that's not the narrative that's popular in our society.

We'll continue discussing some of these things in a moment, but I want to walk through a series of events that unfolded in the last few days that you've shared with me about men and praising men.  Let's start off with Bettina Arndt's tweet.  here relating to the bushfire effort and she's tweeted out a photo of a man fighting a bushfire.  but tina arndt has tweeted our media is full of images of brave men fighting the ferocious fires.  as always it's usually men who do the really dangerous difficult work protecting everyone else.  give thanks for the good in men.  why did you send that out there patina?

because i was watching all these men out there doing this horrendously difficult job, dangerous job.  And I thought, why don't we ever talk about the fact that they're mainly men who still do all these things?

And I would have thought that 90% of the population would agree with the sentiment in that tweet and that photo. i mean the overwhelming reaction is to say anything good about men means i'm denigrating women and denying that there are female firefighters.  of course there are female fighters.  i'm just saying most of the firefighters overwhelmingly are male and of course the stats bear that out.

and of course the men are protecting.  uh men women and children and the property thereof.  let's have a look at this though that uh moira rayner uh who retweeted your image then bought into the argument.  she said that's a woman firefighter.  she was trying to pick you up saying it was a woman firefighter. And she, in relation to that photo, said I was being presumptuous and foolish.
No, you were just actually factual.  It wasn't like... Factual.
And all of them, all the major feminists were out.  There were 5,000 likes for her tweet saying, hooray, you know, up you, Bettina, you know.
And they were wrong.
But it's not relevant, of course.  If it had been a photo of a female fighter, so what?  The point I was making was real.  But it's mainly men and you're not allowed to say that.
Yeah, we ought to praise this masculinity.  This is the masculinity that we ought to aspire to, isn't it?
Well, it's one aspect, a wonderful thing about men, the fact that they still are willing to put their lives on the line for us.

Well, this is an amazing space you've gotten into now, isn't it?  This is what you're doing day in, day out, arguing that men should be valued and praised as well, and yet you draw so much fire from the feminists.

That's right.  And I think this is a classic example of the fact that the whole debate has got so warped that to say anything good about men is seen as denigrating women, that you can't ever talk about anything in terms of that's good in masculinity without someone jumping on you and constant lies and misinformation.
